segment.target: Checklist Creating Group Policy Objects (Windows 10)

segment.target: Checklist Creating Group Policy Objects

segment.source: Checklist: Creating Group Policy Objects
segment.target: Checklist: Creating Group Policy Objects

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: To deploy firewall or IPsec settings or firewall or connection security rules, we recommend that you use Group Policy in AD DS.
segment.target: To deploy firewall or IPsec settings or firewall or connection security rules, we recommend that you use Group Policy in AD DS.

segment.source: This section describes a tested, efficient method that requires some up-front work, but serves an administrator well in the long run by making GPO assignments as easy as dropping a device into a membership group.
segment.target: This section describes a tested, efficient method that requires some up-front work, but serves an administrator well in the long run by making GPO assignments as easy as dropping a device into a membership group.

segment.source: The checklists for firewall, domain isolation, and server isolation include a link to this checklist.
segment.target: The checklists for firewall, domain isolation, and server isolation include a link to this checklist.

segment.source: About membership groups
segment.target: About membership groups

segment.source: For most GPO deployment tasks, you must determine which devices must receive and apply which GPOs.
segment.target: For most GPO deployment tasks, you must determine which devices must receive and apply which GPOs.

segment.source: Because different versions of Windows can support different settings and rules to achieve similar behavior, you might need multiple GPOs: one for each operating system that has settings different from the others to achieve the same result.
segment.target: Because different versions of Windows can support different settings and rules to achieve similar behavior, you might need multiple GPOs: one for each operating system that has settings different from the others to achieve the same result.

segment.source: For example, Windows 10, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008, and Windows Server 2008 R2 use rules and settings that are incompatible with Windows 2000, Windows XP, and Windows Server 2003.
segment.target: For example, Windows 10, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008, and Windows Server 2008 R2 use rules and settings that are incompatible with Windows 2000, Windows XP, and Windows Server 2003.

segment.source: Therefore, if your network included those older operating systems you would need to create a GPO for each set of operating systems that can share common settings.
segment.target: Therefore, if your network included those older operating systems you would need to create a GPO for each set of operating systems that can share common settings.

segment.source: To deploy typical domain isolation settings and rules, you might have five different GPOs for the versions of Windows discussed in this guide.
segment.target: To deploy typical domain isolation settings and rules, you might have five different GPOs for the versions of Windows discussed in this guide.

segment.source: By following the procedures in this guide, you only need one membership group to manage all five GPOs.
segment.target: By following the procedures in this guide, you only need one membership group to manage all five GPOs.

segment.source: The membership group is identified in the security group filter for all five GPOs.
segment.target: The membership group is identified in the security group filter for all five GPOs.

segment.source: To apply the settings to a device, you make that device's account a member of the membership group.
segment.target: To apply the settings to a device, you make that device's account a member of the membership group.

segment.source: WMI filters are used to ensure that the correct GPO is applied.
segment.target: WMI filters are used to ensure that the correct GPO is applied.

segment.source: About exclusion groups
segment.target: About exclusion groups

segment.source: A Windows Firewall with Advanced Security design must often take into account domain-joined devices on the network that cannot or must not apply the rules and settings in the GPOs.
segment.target: A Windows Firewall with Advanced Security design must often take into account domain-joined devices on the network that cannot or must not apply the rules and settings in the GPOs.

segment.source: Because these devices are typically fewer in number than the devices that must apply the GPO, it is easier to use the Domain Members group in the GPO membership group, and then place these exception devices into an exclusion group that is denied Apply Group Policy permissions on the GPO.
segment.target: Because these devices are typically fewer in number than the devices that must apply the GPO, it is easier to use the Domain Members group in the GPO membership group, and then place these exception devices into an exclusion group that is denied Apply Group Policy permissions on the GPO.

segment.source: Because deny permissions take precedence over allow permissions, a device that is a member of both the membership group and the exception group is prevented from applying the GPO.
segment.target: Because deny permissions take precedence over allow permissions, a device that is a member of both the membership group and the exception group is prevented from applying the GPO.

segment.source: Devices typically found in a GPO exclusion group for domain isolation include the domain controllers, DHCP servers, and DNS servers.
segment.target: Devices typically found in a GPO exclusion group for domain isolation include the domain controllers, DHCP servers, and DNS servers.

segment.source: You can also use a membership group for one zone as an exclusion group for another zone.
segment.target: You can also use a membership group for one zone as an exclusion group for another zone.

segment.source: For example, devices in the boundary and encryption zones are technically in the main domain isolation zone, but must apply only the GPO for their assigned role.
segment.target: For example, devices in the boundary and encryption zones are technically in the main domain isolation zone, but must apply only the GPO for their assigned role.

segment.source: To do this, the GPOs for the main isolation zone deny Apply Group Policy permissions to members of the boundary and encryption zones.
segment.target: To do this, the GPOs for the main isolation zone deny Apply Group Policy permissions to members of the boundary and encryption zones.

segment.source: Checklist: Creating Group Policy objects
segment.target: Checklist: Creating Group Policy objects

segment.source: Task
segment.target: Task

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: Review important concepts and examples for deploying GPOs in a way that best meets the needs of your organization.
segment.target: Review important concepts and examples for deploying GPOs in a way that best meets the needs of your organization.

segment.source: Identifying Your Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Deployment Goals
segment.target: Identifying Your Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Deployment Goals

segment.source: Planning Group Policy Deployment for Your Isolation Zones
segment.target: Planning Group Policy Deployment for Your Isolation Zones

segment.source: Create the membership group in AD DS that will be used to contain device accounts that must receive the GPO.
segment.target: Create the membership group in AD DS that will be used to contain device accounts that must receive the GPO.

segment.source: If some devices in the membership group are running an operating system that does not support WMI filters, such as Windows 2000, create an exclusion group to contain the device accounts for the devices that cannot be blocked by using a WMI filter.
segment.target: If some devices in the membership group are running an operating system that does not support WMI filters, such as Windows 2000, create an exclusion group to contain the device accounts for the devices that cannot be blocked by using a WMI filter.

segment.source: Create a Group Account in Active Directory
segment.target: Create a Group Account in Active Directory

segment.source: Create a GPO for each version of Windows that has different implementation requirements.
segment.target: Create a GPO for each version of Windows that has different implementation requirements.

segment.source: Create a Group Policy Object
segment.target: Create a Group Policy Object

segment.source: Create security group filters to limit the GPO to only devices that are members of the membership group and to exclude devices that are members of the exclusion group.
segment.target: Create security group filters to limit the GPO to only devices that are members of the membership group and to exclude devices that are members of the exclusion group.

segment.source: Assign Security Group Filters to the GPO
segment.target: Assign Security Group Filters to the GPO

segment.source: Create WMI filters to limit each GPO to only the devices that match the criteria in the filter.
segment.target: Create WMI filters to limit each GPO to only the devices that match the criteria in the filter.

segment.source: Create WMI Filters for the GPO
segment.target: Create WMI Filters for the GPO

segment.source: If you are working on a GPO that was copied from another, modify the group memberships and WMI filters so that they are correct for the new zone or version of Windows for which this GPO is intended.
segment.target: If you are working on a GPO that was copied from another, modify the group memberships and WMI filters so that they are correct for the new zone or version of Windows for which this GPO is intended.

segment.source: Modify GPO Filters to Apply to a Different Zone or Version of Windows
segment.target: Modify GPO Filters to Apply to a Different Zone or Version of Windows

segment.source: Link the GPO to the domain level of the Active Directory organizational unit hierarchy.
segment.target: Link the GPO to the domain level of the Active Directory organizational unit hierarchy.

segment.source: Link the GPO to the Domain
segment.target: Link the GPO to the Domain

segment.source: Before adding any rules or configuring the GPO, add a few test devices to the membership group, and make sure that the correct GPO is received and applied to each member of the group.
segment.target: Before adding any rules or configuring the GPO, add a few test devices to the membership group, and make sure that the correct GPO is received and applied to each member of the group.

segment.source: Add Test Devices to the Membership Group for a Zone
segment.target: Add Test Devices to the Membership Group for a Zone
